articles.author: Dimitri 'phaazon' Sabadie <dimitri.sabadie@gmail.com>
articles.description:
Neovim Core updates
Updates of Neovim itself, which are available on Neovim nightly.
Important: some updates might be missing from this week content. If you want to be sure to always keep up to
date with what’s going on in Neovim Core, you are strongly advised to have a look to these places:
@neovim on Twitter, which tweets the most recent news about the editor.
:h news.txt will deliver you with the last news inside Neovim directly.
Various PRs on GitHub.
#22668 adds lua-loader.
A builtin Lua module which byte-compiles and caches Lua files (speeds up load times). To enable, add
vim.loader.enable() to your init.lua.
Neovim Plugin Community updates
Neovim is full of active plugins. This section is about the community and what is going on.
Need help

      
      Something explaining what is …

Neovim Core updates
Updates of Neovim itself, which are available on Neovim nightly.
Important: if you are a plugin author, you are strongly advised to follow the
#14090 breaking changes on master GitHub thread, as it contains
important breaking changes information.
Breaking changes are now tracked in :help news

Breaking changes are now tracked in :help news
You can subscribe via…

RSS: http://github.com/neovim/neovim/commits/master/runtime/doc/news.txt.atom
Third-party service: enter https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/master/runtime/doc/news.txt at https://app.github-file-watcher.com/
Where possible, breaking changes are also flagged with vim.deprecate()

articles.author: mattpolito
articles.description:
configuration of your rubygems via the .gemrc file but now you want to bypass that.
--norc flag will do just that:
gem install decent_exposure --norc
.gemrc will be ignored.
Rubygems documentation
articles.title: Disable gemrc configuration - #ruby

articles.author: mattpolito
articles.description:
.gemrc if you don't already have one and add:
gem: --no-document
--no-ri & --no-rdoc, however --no-document takes care of both.
gem documentation for more info
articles.title: Don't auto generate Gem documentation in Ruby - #ruby

articles.author: mattpolito
articles.description:
a situation which caused the need to potentially remove Github's keys from your known_hosts file.
ssh-keygen -R github.com
ssh-keygen -R 140.82.114.4
ssh-keygen -R 140.82.113.3
github's meta information endpoint to find address ranges, but that's a problem for a more clever person.
articles.title: Remove SSH keys from known host file by IP address - #command-line

articles.author: mattpolito
articles.description:
Swagger UI is a great way to view API documentation. It's even got a cool feature where you can excercise the api right from the documentation.
Swagger UI documentation shows a configuration option called tryItOutEnabled. This sounds promising and the description even states:
how to configure Swagger UI through rswag, we try:
Rswag::Ui.configure do |c|
  c.config_object["tryItOutEnabled"] = false
end
supportedSubmitMethods and provide an empty array, we'll get something more usable.
Rswag::Ui.configure do |c|
  c.config_object["supportedSubmitMethods"] = []
end

Now the button will completely disappear!
articles.title: Disable "Try it out" feature of Swagger UI - #ruby

articles.author: mattpolito
articles.description:
rswag contains the library Swagger UI. This allows your generated documentation to be viewable from your webserver. 
Rswag::Ui.configure do |c|
  c.config_object["showExtensions"] = true
end
config_object. It is just a hash that you can set with keys that match available options found in Swagger UI's configuration docs
articles.title: Configure Swagger UI when using rubygem rswag - #ruby

articles.author: mattpolito
articles.description:
Heroku console?
heroku run "rails console -- --nomultiline"

Now it'll be disabled for that console session.
articles.title: Disable ruby console autocomplete in Heroku - #ruby

articles.author: craighafer
articles.description:
Date#commercial is what you're looking for! It will create a Date object for you based on the year,week,  and day that you give it.
require 'date'

# Wednesday (3) of week 1 of year 2023
Date.commercial(2023, 1, 3)
Date.commercial(Date.current.year, Date.current.cweek, 5)
Rails TimeHelpers to travel to that specific date you need:
next_friday = Date.commercial(Date.current.year, Date.current.cweek + 1, 5)

travel_to next_friday do
  # Friday specific code
end
articles.title: Create a Date object for a specific day - #ruby
